raw_text:
Creator of first Apple Mac dies
 
 Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer, has died.
 
 Mr Raskin was one of the first employees at Apple and made many of the design decisions that made the Mac so distinctive when it was first released. He led the team that decided to use a graphical interface and mouse that let people navigate around the computer by pointing and clicking. The 1984 release of the Mac reflected Mr Raskin's belief that good design should make computers easy to use.
 
 Mr Raskin joined Apple in 1978 as employee number 31, initially to lead the company's publications department. However, in 1979 he was put in charge of a small team to design a computer that lived up to his idea of a machine that was cheap, aimed at consumers rather than computer professionals and was very easy to use.
 
 The result was the 1984 Macintosh that did away with the then common text-based interface in favour of one based around graphics that resembled a virtual desktop and used folders and documents. Users navigated around the machine using a mouse and by pointing, clicking and dragging. Although now in common use in almost all computers, these methods were pioneering when first used in the Macintosh. The GUI was developed by Xerox PARC, and used in its Star machine. But the acceptance of the interface did not truly begin until the concept was developed for use by Apple in its pioneering Lisa computer. "His role on the Macintosh was the initiator of the project, so it wouldn't be here if it weren't for him," said Andy Hertzfeld, an early Macintosh team member. Although Mr Raskin drove the team that created the Macintosh he did not stay at Apple to see it released. In 1981 he was removed from the project following a dispute with Apple's mercurial boss Steve Jobs. In 1982, Mr Raskin left Apple entirely. The Macintosh was reputedly named after Mr Raskin's favourite apple, though the name was changed slightly following a trademark dispute with another company. After leaving Apple, Mr Raskin founded another company called Information Appliance and continued to work on better ways to interface with computers. He was also an accomplished musician, played three instruments and conducted San Francisco's Chamber Opera Society. Mr Raskin was diagnosed in December 2004 with pancreatic cancer and died on 26 February at his home in California.
llama3.2:1b: Jef Raskin, head of the Macintosh team, has died.
Raskin was a key figure in designing the first Apple Macintosh computer.
He worked at Apple from 1978 to 1982, leading the design of the machine that incorporated a graphical user interface and mouse.
Raskin led a small team that developed the GUI for the Macintosh, which was influenced by earlier interfaces used on other computers like Xerox PARC's Star machine.
The idea of using folders and documents to organize files did not become standard until Apple developed it for the Lisa computer.
Raskin drove his own design, but left Apple in 1981 after a dispute with Steve Jobs.
He founded another company called Information Appliance and continued to work on improving computer interfaces.
llama3.2:3b: Jef Raskin, Apple employee number 31 who led the team behind the first Macintosh computer, has died of pancreatic cancer at age unknown, leaving behind a legacy as one of the key creators of the graphical user interface that made the Mac so distinctive.
gemma2:2b: Jef Raskin, creator of the first Macintosh computer, has passed away.
He joined Apple in 1978 and led the team responsible for the innovative graphical user interface (GUI) that made the Mac popular.
He left Apple in 1982 following a dispute with Steve Jobs but continued his work on computer interfaces and was an accomplished musician.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Jef Raskin, a key figure behind the first Macintosh computer, has passed away.
He joined Apple in 1978 as an employee number 31 and oversaw the design of the interface that would become familiar to many people today—using a graphical mouse instead of a cursor.
His contributions include developing the GUI (General User Interface) at Xerox PARC, which is still used by many computers today.
Despite his importance in Apple's development process, Mr. Raskin did not stay with the company for much longer after leaving to make the Lisa computer.
He was replaced by Steve Jobs' "Mercury" team and later joined Information Appliance, but he continued working on ways of interworking computers.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Jef Raskin, Apple co-founder known for designing the Macintosh computer, dies at age 71.
qwen2.5:3b: Jef Raskin, the creator of the first Macintosh computer, has passed away.
He joined Apple in 1978 to design a user-friendly machine aimed at consumers rather than professionals.
The team he led developed the graphical interface and mouse features that made navigation intuitive for users.
The Macintosh's success influenced other companies like Xerox with their Star system.
However, Raskin was removed from the project in 1981 due to a conflict with Apple CEO Steve Jobs.
After leaving Apple, Raskin founded Information Appliance and continued working on user interface improvements.
He also pursued his passion for music, playing multiple instruments and conducting an opera group.
Raskin died of pancreatic cancer at age 70 in California in February 2006.
opencoder:1.5b: The creator of the first Apple Macintosh dies, following the events of its release, while leading a team to create a distinctively different computer from the established Apple hardware.
smollm:1.7b: Jef Raskin, the head of Apple's design team, has passed away.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Jef Raskin was the CEO of Apple's team that created the first Macintosh computer in 1984, driving a graphical interface with mouse and folders to make computers intuitive for users.
He joined in 1978, leading Apple's design efforts towards a text-based interface while later taking on management roles as an employee number 31 and managing a team tasked with designing the Mac.
His leadership led to the introduction of folders and documents, changing computing history.
He was also known for his career achievements, including founding Information Appliance and conducting music performance work.
Raskin passed away in 2004 from pancreatic cancer after serving as Apple's CEO.
tinyllama:1.1b: Creator of first Apple Mac dies, leaving behind groundbreaking design that revolutionized personal computing.
Jef Raskin, who played a key role in developing the Macintosh, a graphical interface that made computers user-friendly, died on February 26th at his home in California.
In 1978, he was put in charge of a small team to design an Apple computer that would be affordable and easy to use for consumer users.
Despite their success in developing the Macintosh, Raskin faced accusations from Steve Jobs, who eventually sacked him and led another company called Information Appliance.

Although Raskin's role on the Macintosh was not permanent, he continued to work on ways to make computers easier to use and played a key part in pioneering graphical interfaces for personal computers.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Jef Raskin, who helped design the first Apple Macintosh, has passed away.
He made many of the design decisions that made the Mac unique and was one of the first employees at Apple.
Before joining the company, he worked on the Star machine, which used a similar graphical interface to the Macintosh.
His role in the Macintosh project was initiated by Xerox PARC's Steve Jobs, who wanted to create a computer that people could easily use.
However, there were disagreements between Mr. Raskin and Apple's boss Steve Jobs, and Mr. Raskin was removed from the project in 1981.
He founded another company called Information Appliance after leaving Apple, and continued to work on better ways to interface with computers as well as other music-related endeavors.
phi:2.7b: Jef Raskin, head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer, has passed away after a battle with pancreatic cancer.
He is credited with pioneering the graphical user interface (GUI) used in modern computers, which he believed should be easy to use for consumers rather than professionals.
The Macintosh's success reflected his design decisions and his role as an innovator in technology.
orca-mini:3b: Jef Raskin, the head of the team behind the first Macintosh computer, has died.
He was one of the first employees at Apple and led the team that decided to use a graphical interface and mouse that let people navigate around the computer by pointing and clicking.
The 1984 release of the Mac reflected Mr Raskin's belief that good design should make computers easy to use.
The Macintosh was renamed after him, though the name was changed slightly following a trademark dispute with another company.
After leaving Apple, Mr Raskin founded another company called Information Appliance and continued to work on better ways to interface with computers.
He was also an accomplished musician, played three instruments and conducted San Francisco's Chamber Opera Society.
hermes3:3b: Jef Raskin, Apple employee #31, designed first Macintosh & led team for graphical user interface.
Died (1981) after creating the 1984 release Mac, which pioneered GUI & mouse-based navigation.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Jef Raskin, the creator of the first Apple Mac, passed away after battling pancreatic cancer.
He played a significant role in designing the groundbreaking Macintosh computer by leading the team that chose a graphical interface and mouse, making it easy to use for consumers.
Raskin joined Apple in 1978 as employee number 31, initially working on the company's publications department, before taking charge of the Macintosh project in 1979.
The Macintosh, released in 1984, revolutionized computer design by replacing text-based interfaces with graphics and using folders and documents.
After leaving Apple in 1982, Raskin continued to work on improving computer interface methods and founded Information Appliance.
He was also an accomplished musician.
stablelm2:1.6b: Jef Raskin, creator of the first Macintosh computer, has passed away.
He led the team that introduced a graphical interface and mouse allowing users to navigate their computers by pointing and clicking.
The Macintosh was revolutionary for its use of graphics-based user interface which resembled a virtual desktop.
This concept was initially developed for Apple in 1984 with the Lisa computer but took off with Raskin's creation, the Macintosh.
His influence on the project led to the creation of the pioneering GUI that is now commonly used across all computers.
Raskin founded another company after leaving Apple called Information Appliance, where he continued working on ways to interface with computers.
He was also an accomplished musician, playing three instruments and conducting a San Francisco Chamber Opera Society.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Jef Raskin, a key figure in the creation of Apple's first Macintosh computer, passed away in 2023 due to pancreatic cancer.
Hired as employee number 31 at Apple in 1978, he led the team that designed the iconic 1984 Macintosh, emphasizing user-friendly design with a graphical interface and mouse navigation.
Raskin's vision of a cheap, consumer-oriented computer revolutionized computing by introducing a virtual desktop, folders, and documents—features now standard in modern computers.
His role as the project initiator is crucial to the Macintosh's existence.
After a dispute with Steve Jobs in 1981, Raskin departed Apple and founded Information Appliance, focusing on improving computer interfaces.
In his later years, he remained an accomplished musician, conducting San Francisco's Chamber Opera Society.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Jef Raskin, the creator of the first Apple Macintosh, has died.
He was an early Apple employee and led the team that designed the Mac with a graphical interface and mouse, making computers easier to use.
Raskin joined Apple in 1978 and envisioned a consumer-friendly, affordable machine.
His work led to the 1984 Macintosh, which replaced text-based interfaces with a graphical desktop, pioneering point-and-click navigation.
Although the GUI concept originated at Xerox PARC, Apple popularized it.
Raskin initiated the Macintosh project but left Apple in 1982 after a dispute with Steve Jobs.
He later founded Information Appliance and continued working on computer interfaces.
Also a musician, he played three instruments and conducted an opera society.
Diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in December 2004, he died on 26 February at his California home.
